---

## GAD-7 vs DAST

GAD-7 vs DAST In the field of psychological research, the comparison or harmonisation between different questionnaires is a necessary but time-consuming task for researchers. As an example, comparing Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7), a seven-item instrument used to assess the severity of anxiety, with the Drug Abuse Screening Test (DAST), a drug abuse detection tool, can be challenging due to the different focuses and terminologies of these two assessments. By using the innovative software tool, Harmony, this process can be significantly simplified. With its advanced natural language processing and generative AI capability, Harmony serves as a bridge between the GAD-7 and DAST. It matches and compares questionnaire items effectively, saving researchers from going through tremendous paperwork. It provides a clear percentage match between each item in GAD-7 and DAST, enabling researchers to draw valid and convincing comparative conclusions in relation to anxiety and drug abuse. Additionally, Harmony also supports the comparison of tools in multiple languages, broadening its applications across culturally diverse researches. To employ Harmony in your research when dealing with GAD-7 vs DAST, simply choose the assessments from Harmony's database or upload your own instruments in PDF form via Harmony's intuitive web interface. The result generated by Harmony not only increases the efficiency of your research process but also enhances the accuracy and consistency of comparative studies involving GAD-7 and DAST.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
